In terms of cause and effect, the Buddha is the cause, the Dharma Jewel is the effect;
The Saá¹…gha is the cause, the Dharma Jewel is the effect.
In terms of the path and its fruits, the Buddha is the path, the Dharma Jewel is the fruit;
The Saá¹…gha is the path, and the Dharma Jewel is the fruit.
The Buddha takes the Dharma as his teacher, and the Buddha is born from the Dharma;
The Dharma is the mother of the Buddha, and the Buddha abides in dependence on the Dharma.
A question was asked:
If the Buddha takes the Dharma as his teacher, why is the Dharma not placed first among the Three Jewels?
An answer was given:
Although the Dharma is the teacher of the Buddha, without the Buddha to promote it, the Dharma would not flourish. The Way is promoted by people. Therefore, the Buddha is placed first.
At that time, UpÄli again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If when receiving the three refuges and precepts, one first mentions the Dharma Jewel and then the Buddha, does it still constitute the three refuges?
He replied:
If one does not understand and recites them in the wrong order, one does not incur an offense and it still constitutes the three refuges.
If one understands but deliberately recites them in the wrong order, one incurs an offense and it does not constitute the three refuges.
A question was asked:

If one takes refuge in the Buddha and the Dharma, but not in the Sangha, does it constitute the Three Refuges?ğŸ”½If one takes refuge in the Dharma and the Sangha, but not in the Buddha, does it constitute the Three Refuges?
If one takes refuge in the Buddha and the Sangha, but not in the Dharma Jewel, does it constitute the Three Refuges?
The answer is:
It does not constitute the Three Refuges.
The question is:
If one does not take the Three Refuges, can one receive the five precepts?
If one does not take the Three Refuges, can one receive the eight precepts?
If one does not take the Three Refuges, can one receive the ten precepts?
If one does not undergo the four announcements and karman, can one receive the full precepts?
The answer is:
None of them can be received.
If one receives the five precepts, one must first take the Three Refuges. Only after the Three Refuges are completed can one receive the five precepts.
The reason for explaining the names of the five precepts is to make the person in front understand the names of the precepts.
It is like the full precepts, which are received after the four announcements and karman are completed.
Therefore, the four bases and four offenses, and the thirteen saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£as, are only taught for the sake of knowledge.
It is also said:
After receiving the three refuges, when the precept against killing is explained, at that time one receives the precepts.
The reason for saying that by receiving one precept, one receives the five precepts, is that if one can uphold one precept, one can uphold all five.
Moreover, because the power of the five precepts is mutually connected, and because one originally vows to receive the five precepts.
It is also said:
After receiving the five precepts, one then receives the precepts.
Among the various explanations, the correct principle is that one receives the five precepts after receiving the three refuges.
It is like the method of the four-part white karma. If one receives the eight precepts or the ten precepts, it is explained like the five precepts.
If one first receives the three refuges and becomes an upÄsaka, and later receives the five precepts, the eight precepts, or the ten precepts, does one need the three refuges again?
The answer:
One does not receive the three refuges.
All who receive the precepts do so by first taking the Three Refuges.
If one does not first take the Three Refuges but directly receives the precepts through the white four karman, can one obtain the precepts?
The answer is:
For the five precepts, eight precepts, and ten precepts, one only needs to take the Three Refuges and one will immediately obtain the precepts.
But for receiving the full precepts, one must use the white four karman to obtain the full precepts, not just the Three Refuges.

Those who receive the full precepts have profound and weighty merits and virtues. Without many conditions and much effort, it cannot be accomplished. Therefore, one must take the Three Refuges, have ten monks, and perform the white four karman before one can obtain them.

The merits and virtues of the five precepts, eight precepts, and ten precepts are lesser, so if one receives the Three Refuges, one will immediately obtain the precepts, and there is no need for many conditions and much effort.
After receiving the full precepts, why are only the four pÄrÄjikas and thirteen saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£as explained, and not the other sections?
These two sections of precepts are the most serious.
If one precept is violated, it will never arise again.
Although it is difficult to arouse, if one is on probation or in a period of penance, one may later be released from offenses in a group of twenty.

If it is difficult to uphold but one is able to uphold it, the precepts of the other sections are easy to uphold, so there is no need to explain them. Therefore, only two sections are explained, not the other sections.
Question:
Is this prÄtimoká¹£a precept a pure precept?
Is it a dhyÄna precept?
Answer:
It is neither a pure precept nor a dhyÄna precept.
This prÄtimoká¹£a precept exists only when the Buddha is in the world;
when the Buddha is not in the world, this precept does not exist.
The dhyÄna and pure precepts exist at all times, whether the Buddha is in the world or not.
The prÄtimoká¹£a precept is obtained from instruction, but the dhyÄna and pure precepts are not obtained from instruction;
The precepts of the PÄrÄjika are obtained from others, but the precepts of dhyÄna and the undefiled are not obtained from others.
The precepts of the PÄrÄjika are present at all times, regardless of whether one is sleeping or not, and regardless of whether one's mind is good, evil, or neutral;
The precepts of dhyÄna and the undefiled are present only when the mind is in dhyÄna or the undefiled state, and not present in any other state of mind.
The precepts of the PÄrÄjika are only present among humans, but the precepts of dhyÄna and the undefiled are present among both humans and gods;
The precepts of the PÄrÄjika are only present in the desire realm, but the precepts of dhyÄna and the undefiled are accomplished in both the desire and form realms;
The precepts of the PÄrÄjika are only present among the disciples of the Buddha, but the precepts of dhyÄna are present among both Buddhists and non-Buddhists.
Question:
Among the five precepts for upÄsakas, how many are real offenses?
How many are prohibited offenses?
Answer:
Four are real offenses, and the precept against drinking alcohol is a prohibited offense.
The reason why drinking alcohol is grouped together with the four offenses to form the five precepts is because drinking alcohol is the root of negligence, and one can violate the four precepts.
As in the time of KÄÅ›yapa Buddha, there was an upÄsaka who, due to drinking alcohol, had sexual relations with another's wife and stole and killed another's chicken.
Other people asked him:
Why do you do this?
He replied:
I don't do it.
Due to the confusion caused by alcohol, he was able to break the four precepts at once.
There are those who, due to drinking alcohol, are able to commit the four grave offenses, but only cannot break the precepts of the Sangha.
Although it is not past karma, there is a karmic retribution of madness, and due to drinking alcohol, one becomes confused and disordered, just like a madman.
Moreover, due to the confusion caused by alcohol, one neglects one's proper dutiesâ€”sitting in meditation, reciting scriptures, and assisting in the affairs of the Sangha.
Although it is not a real offense, due to these causes and conditions, it is the same as a real offense.
UpÄli again addressed the Buddha, saying:
The upÄsaka precepts are only obtained in relation to sentient beings. Can one also obtain the precepts in relation to non-sentient beings?
Are the precepts only obtained in relation to sentient beings who can be killed, stolen from, had sexual relations with, or lied to?
Or are the precepts also obtained in relation to sentient beings who cannot be killed, stolen from, had sexual relations with, or deceived?
The answer is:
The four precepts are obtained in relation to sentient beings, and the precept against drinking alcohol is obtained in relation to non-sentient beings.
Whether sentient beings can be killed or not, can be had sexual relations with or not, can be stolen from or not, can be lied to or not, one obtains the precepts in all cases.
From the AvÄ«ci hell below to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception above, and in the trichiliocosm, up to the TathÄgatas, all living beings obtain these four precepts.
Because when one first receives the precepts, one does not kill, steal, engage in sexual misconduct, or lie at all, without any limits. For this reason, all sentient beings can receive the precepts.
The method of receiving the precepts is to first explain the Dharma to guide and enlighten the practitioner, causing them to give rise to a compassionate mind towards all sentient beings.
Having attained the superior mind, one then attains the superior precepts.
The method of receiving the precepts is to receive four precepts from each and every sentient being.
The four precepts are distinguished into twelve precepts.
Towards sentient beings, one does not kill, steal, engage in sexual misconduct, or lie. The arising of these four evils has three causes:
First, they arise due to greed;
Second, they arise due to anger;
Third, they arise due to delusion.
There are twelve evils towards all sentient beings. By reversing these evils, one attains the twelve wholesome precepts.
It is the same for all sentient beings, who are limitless.

Even if there are a million or ten million arhats who enter nirvana, the precepts that were originally obtained by these arhats are accomplished from beginning to end, and are not lost just because the arhats have entered nirvana.

When one obtains the precept against drinking alcohol, in this lifetime, in the three thousand worlds, for all the alcohol that exists, with each swallow, one obtains the form of the precept, because when one receives the precepts, one completely abstains from drinking all alcohol.
Even if the alcohol becomes extinct, the precepts are always accomplished and not lost.
When one first receives the precepts, one obtains the precept against sexual misconduct in the three orifices of all women, but then marries a wife, does one violate this precept?
He replied:
One does not violate it.
The reason is this: Originally, one obtained the precept against sexual misconduct in relation to others' wives.
Now, it is one's own wife, and since it is not sexual misconduct, one does not violate this precept.
By this principle, all are the same.
The eight precepts and ten precepts, for sentient beings and non-sentient categories, obtaining the precepts is also like this, with two hundred and fifty precepts.
All sentient beings each obtain seven precepts, analyzed by principle, there are twenty-one precepts.
As for one sentient being, the seven evils of body and speech arise. In general, these evils arise from three causes:
First, they arise due to greed;
Second, they arise due to hatred;
Third, they arise due to delusion.
These seven evils arise from three causes, three times seven is twenty-one evils. Opposing evil and obtaining the precepts, on one sentient being one obtains the color of twenty-one precepts.
All sentient beings are also like this.
By this principle, one can obtain immeasurable precepts at one time;
One cannot violate them all at once, and obtain the abandonment of precepts at one time.
As for the method of breaking the precepts, if one breaks the grave precepts, there is no further progress.
Even if one abandons the precepts and receives them again later, one cannot obtain the precepts again.

If one breaks a major precept among the eight precepts, and later takes the eight precepts again, or receives the five precepts, ten precepts, or full precepts, as well as the precepts of meditation and the precepts of no outflows, none of them can be obtained.

If one breaks a major precept among the five precepts, and then receives the eight precepts, ten precepts, full precepts, precepts of meditation, and precepts of no outflows, none of them can be obtained.
If one breaks the five precepts and wishes to abandon the five precepts to receive the ten precepts, there is no such case.

If one abandons the precepts and receives the five precepts again, or receives the eight precepts, ten precepts, full precepts, precepts of meditation, and precepts of no outflows, none of them can be obtained.
If one breaks a major precept among the ten precepts or full precepts, if one wishes to make progress or abandon the precepts to receive the precepts again, it is explained as in the five precepts.
A question was asked:
Among the three precepts - the precepts of meditation, the precepts of no outflows, and the precepts of the Vinaya - which precept is the most superior?
Answer:
The precepts of meditation are superior.
Some say:
The precepts of individual liberation.
The reason for this is that if the Buddha appears in the world, these precepts can be obtained;
The precepts of meditation and the precepts of the unconditioned exist at all times.

The precepts of individual liberation can be obtained from all sentient and non-sentient beings, but the precepts of meditation and the precepts of the unconditioned can only be obtained from sentient beings.

The precepts of individual liberation can be obtained through the mind of loving-kindness towards all sentient beings, but the precepts of meditation and the precepts of the unconditioned are not obtained through the mind of loving-kindness.

Those who are able to uphold the Buddha's teachings, who belong to the seven assemblies, who abide in the world, and who continue the path and fruition of the three vehicles without interruption, all take the precepts of individual liberation as their foundation. The precepts of meditation and the precepts of the unconditioned are not like this. Therefore, they are the most honored and supreme in the three realms.
When first receiving the precepts, after the four-part white karma, the precepts are already accomplished.
The form of the precepts in the first moment is called karma, and also called the path of karma.
The form of precepts produced after the second moment of thought is only karma, not a path of karma.
The reason for this is that the form of precepts in the first moment of thought, the intention and vow are fulfilled, and because it includes intention, it is called the path of intentional karma;
Because the previous precepts are the cause, the subsequent form of precepts arises spontaneously, and therefore it is only called karma, not a path of karma.
The precepts in the first moment of thought have both taught and untaught;
The precepts produced subsequently only have the untaught, not the taught.
The precepts in the first moment of thought are also called precepts, also called good conduct, also called discipline;
The precepts produced subsequently also have this meaning.
UpÄli again said to the Buddha:
In the three times, in which time are the precepts obtained?
The answer was:
The precepts are obtained in the present moment of thought.
The past and future are dharmas, not sentient beings, so the precepts are not obtained;
The present moment of thought is a sentient being, so the precepts are obtained.
Asked:
Is the precept obtained in a good mind?
Or in a non-good mind?ğŸ”½Or in a neutral mind?
Or is the precept obtained in a mindless state?
Answered:
All are obtained.

First, with a good mind, one bows to the Sangha, receives the robes and alms bowl, asks for a preceptor, begs for the precepts with vigor, kneels with palms joined, and after the four proclamations of the karman, the continuity of the good mind, the precept color is accomplished. This is called obtaining the precept in a good mind.

If in the preceding sequence of dharmas, one always gives rise to a good mind, performs various teaching activities, and at the time of the four proclamations of the karman, gives rise to thoughts of greed, anger, and other non-good things, the precept color is accomplished in this mind. This is called obtaining the precept in a non-good mind.
It is because of the power of the original good mind and good teaching that one obtains this precept, not because of the power of the non-good mind.

First, with a wholesome mind, one performs the teaching karma, and at the time of the four-announcement karma, whether asleep or in deep sleep, the precepts arise in the mind of sleep. This is called obtaining the precepts from a neutral state of mind.

First, with a wholesome mind, one performs the teaching karma, and at the time of the four-announcement karma, one enters the attainment of cessation. At that very moment, one accomplishes the precepts. This is called obtaining the precepts from a mindless state.
UpÄli again asked the Buddha:
If a layperson does not receive the five precepts but directly receives the ten precepts, can they obtain the precepts?
He replied:
At one time, one obtains both kinds of precepts, obtaining the upÄsaka precepts and the Å›rÄmaá¹‡era precepts.
If one does not receive the five precepts or the ten precepts but directly receives the full precepts, one obtains all three kinds of precepts at once.
UpÄli again asked the Buddha:

If one receives the full precepts and obtains all three kinds of precepts at once, why is it necessary to first receive the five precepts in order, then the ten precepts, and finally the full precepts?
He replied:
Although one can obtain the three kinds of precepts at the same time, one must follow the sequence in order to become defiled and habituated to the Buddha's teachings.
First, one receives the five precepts to subdue oneself, and gradually increases faith and joy. Next, one receives the ten precepts;
having received the ten precepts, one's wholesome roots become deeper, and next one receives the complete precepts.
In this sequence, one obtains the taste of the Buddha's teachings, and the deep joy and firmness are difficult to destroy.
It is like entering the great ocean, gradually going deeper. Entering the ocean of the Buddha's teachings is also like this.
If one receives the complete precepts all at once, one loses the sequence and also violates the dignified deportment.

Furthermore, there are sentient beings who should receive the five precepts and attain the fruit of the path, and there are sentient beings who, because of receiving the ten precepts, attain the fruit of the path. For these various reasons, the Buddha taught this sequence.
If one first receives the five precepts and then receives the ten precepts, when receiving the ten precepts one also accomplishes the two precepts:
the five precepts and the ten precepts;
After receiving the ten precepts, one next receives the full precepts. When receiving the full precepts, one accomplishes three kinds of precepts:
the five precepts, the ten precepts, and the full precepts.

Among the seven kinds of precepts, only the precepts obtained through the white four-part karman are obtained in three stages, while the precepts obtained through the other six kinds of precepts are only obtained in one stage, not in three stages in sequence.
If one obtains the three kinds of precepts in one stage, if one wishes to abandon them, if one says:
I am a novice monk, not a fully ordained monk.
Then one loses the full precepts, but the two kinds of precepts remain:
the five precepts and the ten precepts;
If one says:
I am a lay devotee, not a novice monk.
Then one loses the ten precepts, but the five precepts remain;

If one says that one completely abandons all [precepts], and that one is a lay devotee who has taken refuge, then the three [kinds of precepts] are all lost at once, but the three refuges are not lost;
If one obtains the three kinds of precepts in sequence, the method of abandoning them is as explained in the section on obtaining the precepts in one stage.
If a former upÄsaka goes forth and receives the ten precepts, does he abandon the five precepts?
He replied:
He does not abandon them.
But he loses the name and loses the sequence, but not the precepts.
He loses the name of upÄsaka and gains the name of Å›rÄmaá¹‡era;
he loses the sequence of a layperson and gains the sequence of one who has gone forth.
When a Å›rÄmaá¹‡era receives the full precepts, does he lose the ten precepts and the five precepts?
He replied:
He does not lose them.
But he loses the name and loses the sequence, but not the precepts.
He loses the name of Å›rÄmaá¹‡era and gains the name of bhiká¹£u;
he loses the sequence of a Å›rÄmaá¹‡era and gains the sequence of a bhiká¹£u.
From beginning to end, it is always the precepts, but the name changes according to the time.

It is like a tree's leaves that are green in spring and summer, yellow in autumn, and white in winter. Because they change according to the time, the leaves seem different, but from beginning to end, they are always the same leaf.
Precepts are also like this, always being one precept, but different according to the time.
It is also like milk, curd, butter, and ghee, which have four different times, and although they differ according to the time, they are still the same.
Precepts are also like this, although there are differences in the three times, the precepts are not different.
UpÄli again addressed the Buddha, saying:

Generally, when receiving the precepts of an upÄsaka, if one is unable to fully receive the five precepts, but receives one precept, two precepts, up to four precepts, does one receive the precepts or not?
He replied:
One does not receive them.
If one does not receive them, there is a sutra that says:
'An upÄsaka who observes a small portion of the precepts, an upÄsaka who observes a large portion of the precepts, and an upÄsaka who observes the full portion of the precepts.'
What is the meaning of this?
He replied:
The reason for saying this is to clarify the amount of merit in observing the precepts, not that there are such precepts to be received.
UpÄli again addressed the Buddha, saying:
If one receives the five precepts for one day, two days, up to ten days, can one receive them in this way?ğŸ”½He replied:
He replied:ğŸ”½No, one cannot.
The Buddha originally established the precepts with each having a limit.
If one receives the five precepts, one must keep them for one's entire life;
if one receives the eight precepts, one must receive them for one day and one night. Therefore, it is not possible.
The precepts of the white four karmas have superior, middling, and inferior grades:
the five precepts are the inferior grade of precepts, the ten precepts are the middling grade of precepts, and the complete precepts are the superior grade of precepts.
There are also three grades within the five precepts:
if one receives the precepts with a minor grade of mind, one obtains the minor grade of precepts;
if one receives the precepts with a middling grade of mind, one obtains the middling grade of precepts;
if one receives the precepts with a superior grade of mind, one obtains the superior grade of precepts.
The ten precepts and the complete precepts also each have three grades, as explained in the five precepts.

If one first obtains the precepts with a weak mind, and later receives the ten precepts with an intermediate or superior mind, one first obtains the five precepts, and there is no increase or superiority.
Outside of the five precepts, up to the remaining five precepts such as not eating at improper times, one obtains the five superior precepts.
One first obtains the five precepts, obtaining the original weak level, which are the original weak level five precepts.
With an intermediate or superior mind, one receives the complete precepts, first obtaining the five precepts, and there is no increase or superiority.
Still based on the five precepts, all precepts outside of the five precepts are obtained due to the superior mind at the time of receiving the complete precepts, obtaining the superior precepts.
Based on this, the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts are not obtained again.
In sequential terms, the five precepts are the weak level, the ten precepts are the intermediate level, and the complete precepts are the superior level.
In terms of meaning, it can also be said that the five precepts obtained with a superior mind are the superior precepts;
The middling grade of mind obtains the ten precepts, which is the middling grade of precepts;
The inferior grade of mind obtains the full precepts, which is the inferior grade of precepts.
For this reason, according to the superior, middling, and inferior grades of mind, the precepts obtained are not the same, and there is no fixed limit.
If one requests a preceptor to receive the ten precepts, and the preceptor is not present, one still obtains the ten precepts.
If, when receiving the ten precepts, the preceptor dies, if one hears of the death, one does not obtain the precepts;
If one does not hear of the death, one obtains the precepts.
If one receives the precepts through the fourfold proclamation, if the preceptor is not present, one cannot receive the precepts, because the number of monks is not full.
If the number of monks is full, even if there is no preceptor, one can still receive the precepts.
UpÄli again asked the Buddha:
Can upÄsakas with the five precepts engage in buying and selling?
He replied:
Buying and selling is permitted.
But one cannot engage in the five occupations:
First, one should not engage in the business of buying and selling livestock.
If one has livestock that one wishes to sell directly, it is permitted, but one should not sell them to butchers;
Second, one should not engage in the business of buying and selling bows, arrows, swords, and staves.
If one has these items that one wishes to sell directly, it is permitted;
Third, one should not make a living by selling alcohol.
If one has alcohol that one wishes to sell directly, it is permitted;
Fourth, one should not press oil, because it kills many insects.
In India, it is customary that from Kashmir onwards, pressing oil from seeds that are free of insects is not considered a transgression;
Fifth, one should not engage in the business of dyeing with the five major colors, because it kills many insects.
The dyeing methods of foreign countries such as RÄjagá¹›ha kill many insects, therefore they are not permitted.
This refers to the method of dyeing blue in China, which also kills many insects, and is counted as one of the five major dyeing methods.
UpÄli further said to the Buddha:
The eight precepts are beyond eating after noon, so there are nine precepts. Why are they called eight precepts?
He replied:

The precept of not eating after noon is the essence of the precepts. The eight precepts assist the essence of the precepts and support each other. They are called the eight precepts. Therefore, they are called eight precepts, not nine.
If a person receives the eight precepts, in which of the seven groups does he belong?
Although he does not receive the precepts for life, because he has the precepts for one day and one night, he should be called an upÄsaka.
Some say:
If he is called an upÄsaka, he does not have the precepts for life;
if he is not an upÄsaka, he has the precepts for one day and one night.
He is only called an intermediate person.
There is a sutra that says.
Upagupta again said to the Buddha:
Are there any precepts outside of the seven groups?
He replied:
There are, the eight precepts are.
Based on this principle, if one receives the eight precepts, it is not included in the seven assemblies.
The method of receiving the eight precepts should be stated as for one day and one night, do not kill, making the words clear and concise.
Do not let it be confused with the precepts for life.
Question:
Can the method of receiving the eight precepts be received for two days, three days, up to ten days at one time?
Answer:
The Buddha originally established the precepts for one day and one night, and one cannot exceed the limit.
If one has the ability to receive one day, after it has passed, one can receive them again in sequence.
In this way, according to one's ability, one can receive them for more or less days, not counting the number of days.
The method of receiving the precepts must be received from another person.
From which person should one receive them?
One should receive them from the five assemblies.
After receiving the eight precepts, if one whips and beats sentient beings, the precepts are not pure.
Even if one does not whip and beat on the same day, if one waits until the next day to whip and beat sentient beings, it is also impure.
To put it simply:
If one commits improper actions with the body or speech, although one does not break the fast, there is no pure Dharma;
Even if the body and speech are pure, if the mind gives rise to thoughts of lust, anger, and harm, it is also called an impure fast;
If the three karmas of body, speech, and mind are pure, but one does not cultivate the six recollections, it is also called an impure fast.
Having received the eight precepts, if one diligently cultivates the six recollections, this is called a pure fast.
There is a sutra that says:
If one becomes the king of JambudvÄ«pa, one has sovereignty over all the people, gold, silver, wealth, and treasures in JambudvÄ«pa.
Although one has such merits, if they are divided into sixteen parts, the merits of the king of JambudvÄ«pa are not equal to one-sixteenth.
This refers to the final pure eight precepts.

If a person wishes to take the eight precepts but first indulges in sex, plays music, craves meat, or engages in various kinds of frivolous laughter, and then takes the precepts, it does not matter whether it is before noon or after noon, they will not obtain the precepts.ğŸ”½If one originally has no intention of taking the precepts but engages in various kinds of frivolous activities, and later encounters a good spiritual friend and then takes the precepts, it does not matter whether it is before noon or after noon, they will obtain the precepts.

One can only attain the precepts of evil conduct towards sentient beings, not towards non-sentient beings.
